questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient has presented with left sided unilateral nasal mass and epistaxis. The radiological picture is given in the image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: The most probable diagnosis is inverted papilloma. It typically presents in middle-aged males with unilateral nasal obstruction and epistaxis. On CT imaging, it appears as a unilateral soft tissue mass often originating from the lateral nasal wall or middle meatus, sometimes with bony remodelling or erosion. Unlike Antrochoanal polyps, it does not arise from the maxillary sinus and extend to the choana.

questions.text: Which ethmoid air cell has been marked with red star in the given CT Scan image?
Identify the structure marked with black arrow on nasal endoscopy.

A patient with a history of chronic bacterial sinusitis presents to the emergency department with a very severe headache. Physical examination demonstrates high fever and chills, exophthalmos, papilledema, and nerve palsies of the VI and III cranial nerves on one side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution: The patient's symptoms-severe headache, fever, exophthalmos, papilledema, and cranial nerve palsies-suggest cavernous sinus thrombosis, a life-threatening condition. Rapid imaging is crucial to confirm the diagnosis and assess the extent of the infection. An emergency CT scan is the fastest and most appropriate initial diagnostic step. Early detection allows prompt treatment with antibiotics and possible surgical drainage.

questions.text: A patient presents to her GP with recurrent nosebleeds and also complains of facial fullness and facial pain. Over the past 2 months she has developed progressive shortness of breath and on one occasion she coughed up some blood. On looking through the patient notes, the GP notices that the patient was recently admitted to hospital with hematuria and proteinuria. What would be the most appropriate test to perform?
questions.solution: The combination of upper respiratory symptoms (nosebleeds, facial pain), pulmonary signs (hemoptysis, dyspnea), and renal involvement (hematuria, proteinuria) suggests a systemic vasculitis, particularly Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA). The most appropriate initial test is antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA), which are commonly positive in GPA. Detecting ANCA supports the diagnosis and guides further management. Early diagnosis is crucial to prevent organ damage.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis as per the given image of NCCT nose and paranasal sinuses?
questions.solution: The NCCT image shows heterogeneous hyperdensities within the opacified sinuses, a characteristic finding of allergic fungal rhinosinusitis (AFRS). These hyperdensities represent allergic mucin, which typically contains fungal elements and appears denser than surrounding soft tissue. AFRS often causes expansion of sinuses with bone remodelling or thinning, as seen in the image. This differentiates it from simple chronic rhinosinusitis or polyps, which lack these dense contents and aggressive features.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male patient presented to ENT OPD with the history of nasal obstruction and severe nasal bleeding. The nasal endoscopy picture shows a mass in the choana as given in the image. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution: The image and clinical scenario point to Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA), a benign but highly vascular tumor that occurs almost exclusively in adolescent males. The patient presents with nasal obstruction and recurrent, profuse epistaxis, both hallmark signs of JNA. Endoscopy shows a reddish, lobulated mass in the choana, which is typical for this tumor. Its vascularity makes biopsy risky, so diagnosis is usually confirmed by imaging (CT/MRI).

questions.text: A 52 year adult patient presenting with right side hearing loss has been subjected to audiological investigations and diagnosed to be a case of right sided serous otitis media. What will be the priority in further management of this patient?
questions.solution: In an adult with unilateral serous otitis media, especially without an obvious cause, nasopharyngeal carcinoma must be ruled out. The Eustachian tube can be blocked by a tumor in the nasopharynx, leading to effusion. Therefore, the priority investigation is nasopharyngoscopy and biopsy (Option a) to exclude malignancy.

questions.text: What is the stage of laryngeal carcinoma shown in the given image?
questions.solution: The CT image shows a large laryngeal mass with extra-laryngeal extension, likely invading nearby soft tissues or cartilage, which defines a T4a lesion. The presence of a single ipsilateral lymph node indicates N1, and no distant metastasis makes it M0. Thus, the correct staging is T4aN1M0, indicating advanced laryngeal carcinoma.

questions.text: A patient of thyroid cancer underwent total thyroidectomy. While extubation, the anesthetist noticed that the patient goes into cyanosis as the tube is removed was being extubated. Which of the following could be the cause?
questions.solution: Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) paralysis is a serious complication of thyroid surgery. The RLNs innervate the vocal cords; if both are paralyzed, the vocal cords remain in a midline or paramedian position, obstructing the airway. This can lead to acute airway obstruction, causing stridor, respiratory distress, and cyanosis immediately after extubation. Unilateral RLN injury may cause hoarseness but not life-threatening obstruction. Hence, the correct answer is a. B/L recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis.

questions.text: Following lateral skull base surgery, patient presents with aphonia and aspiration with no improvement seen in next six months of postoperative period. He should be managed by:
questions.solution: The patient has persistent aphonia and aspiration following lateral skull base surgery, which suggests unilateral vocal cord paralysis due to recurrent laryngeal nerve injury. Since there is no improvement after six months, recovery is unlikely. The goal of treatment is to improve glottic closure to restore voice and prevent aspiration. Medialization thyroplasty (Type I thyroplasty) is the procedure of choice—it repositions the paralyzed vocal cord medially. This improves phonation and protects the airway.

questions.text: A singer has undergone thyroid surgery 1 month back. Her recovery has been satisfactory except that she is unable to sing higher notes now. What is the possible nerve injury which could have happened during thyroid surgery of the patient?
questions.solution: The superior laryngeal nerve (external branch) supplies the cricothyroid muscle, which is responsible for tensing the vocal cords to produce high-pitched sounds. Injury to this nerve during thyroid surgery may not affect normal speech significantly but impairs the ability to hit higher musical notes, which is especially noticeable in singers. Since the patient specifically reports difficulty singing high notes, the likely injury is to the superior laryngeal nerve.

choices.text: Cotton-Myer Grade I congenital subglottic stenosis
Cotton-Myer Grade II congenital subglottic stenosis
Cotton-Myer Grade III congenital subglottic stenosis
Cotton-Myer Grade IV congenital subglottic stenosis

questions.text: A 3-month-old child has developed persistent dyspnea and stridor since birth. On CT scan of neck, the subglottic diameter has been found to be less than normal with the 60% obstruction. What is the appropriate Cotton-Myer grading of this case?
questions.solution:
The Cotton-Myer grading system is used to classify subglottic stenosis based on the percentage of airway obstruction.

  • Grade I: <50% obstruction
  • Grade II: 51-70% obstruction
  • Grade III: 71-99% obstruction
  • Grade IV: No detectable lumen

In this case, the child has 60% subglottic obstruction, which falls within the 51-70% range, making it Grade II congenital subglottic stenosis. This grading helps guide management and surgical planning.

questions.text: Interpret the audiogram given in the picture and comment on the most probable diagnosis.
questions.solution: The given audiogram shows unilateral low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear, with normal hearing in the right ear. This rising configuration—greater hearing loss at lower frequencies that improves at higher frequencies—is characteristic of early-stage Meniere's disease. The typical symptoms might include episodic vertigo, tinnitus, and aural fullness.

questions.text: A patient of head injury suffered hearing loss. He has type Ad Tympanogram. How much conductive hearing loss is expected in this patient?
questions.solution: A Type Ad tympanogram indicates a hypermobile tympanic membrane, often due to ossicular chain discontinuity, which can occur after head injury. This condition leads to a significant conductive hearing loss, typically in the range of 45-60 dB, depending on the severity. Among the options, 54 dB (option c) best represents the expected level of conductive loss in such cases, making it the correct answer.

choices.text: Topical antibiotics and decongestants for 4 weeks
IV antibiotics and follow-up after a month

questions.text: A child presented with ear infection with foul-smelling discharge. On further exploration, a small perforation is found in the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane. What would be the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution: A small perforation in the pars flaccida with foul-smelling ear discharge is highly suggestive of atticoantral chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), which raises suspicion for a cholesteatoma. Cholesteatomas can lead to bone erosion and serious complications if not treated. The most appropriate next step is tympanomastoid exploration to assess and remove the disease. Therefore, option (d) is the correct choice.

choices.text: Retracted TM touching long process of incus
TM touching promontory, does not move on siegelization
TM touching promontory but moves on Siegelization

questions.text: Grade 3 Sade classification describing retraction of pars tensa includes:
questions.solution: The Sade classification is used to grade pars tensa retraction of the tympanic membrane. In Grade 3, the tympanic membrane is severely retracted and touches the promontory, but it still retains some mobility. On Siegelization (pneumatic otoscopy), the membrane moves, indicating that it is not yet fixed. Therefore, option (d)-“TM touching promontory but moves on Siegelization”-accurately describes Grade 3 retraction.

questions.text: Patient has the complaint of right sided hearing loss and left ear hearing is normal. Tuning fork tests show that Rinne is negative on right side and positive on left side. Weber test is lateralized toward right ear. Absolute bone conduction (ABC) test is normal both sides. What is the interpretation?
questions.solution: The Rinne test is negative on the right, indicating bone conduction > air conduction, which suggests conductive hearing loss in that ear. The Rinne test is positive on the left, which is normal. The Weber test lateralizes to the right, which further supports conductive hearing loss on the right side (as Weber lateralizes to the affected ear in conductive loss). Absolute bone conduction (ABC) is normal on both sides, ruling out sensorineural loss. Therefore, the findings are consistent with right-sided conductive hearing loss, making option (a) the correct interpretation.

questions.text: Identify the middle ear landmark marked with yellow arrow.
questions.solution: st Sinus tympani, p ponticulus, su subiculum, rw round window, pr promontory, ps posterior sinus, ma malleus, s stapes, in incus, pe pyramidal eminence, fn facial nerve

choices.text: Sensorineural deafness is a common feature
Red bulging tympanic membrane is a common otoscopic finding
Tympanostomy tubes are usually required for treatment
Ear ache is a common symptom

questions.text: In the given condition, which one of the following statements is true?
questions.solution: The image shows a bulging, amber-colored tympanic membrane, suggestive of Otitis Media with Effusion (OME). In this condition, fluid accumulates behind the eardrum without signs of acute infection. Tympanostomy tubes (grommets) are often required to ventilate the middle ear and prevent recurrent fluid buildup. Sensorineural hearing loss is not typical; rather, conductive hearing loss is more common. Redness and earache are more characteristic of acute otitis media, not OME.
